items.description: The most widely used measurement system internationally.
A volume unit mainly used in the United States and the United Kingdom.
A metric unit commonly used in European bars and menus.
A double-sided measuring tool used for accurate pours.
A smaller measure used for modifiers or secondary ingredients.
Pouring without a measuring tool, relying on timing and experience.
A very small amount of liquid, most commonly used for bitters.
A single drop of liquid, smaller than a dash.
A loose, non-precise small amount, usually of a mixer.
A unit used for small liquid quantities, syrups, or liqueurs.
A household measurement sometimes found in older recipes.
The proportional relationship between ingredients, independent of volume units.
An equal amount of each ingredient in a recipe.
A traditional balance between spirit, sour, and sweet components.
Water added to a drink through melting ice during preparation.
Adding a controlled amount of water before serving.
The percentage of alcohol in a liquid.
An alternative system for expressing alcohol strength.
Ensure consistency. Allow accurate recipe replication. Maintain flavor balance. Make recipes universally understandable.
